;日本在最近的一份防务白皮书中将中国称为“最大的战略挑战”，并且尽管分析人士表示，东京的强硬立场“显然是对东南亚的担忧”，但他们指出，“闭门造车”的地区精英可能会理解这种做法。

;

;日本在 2017 年表示，中国构成的挑战是“前所未有的”。该年度报告于7月28日发布，指出北京的对外立场、军事活动和其他行为，称其已成为严重关切。作为回应，中国国防部发言人谭克非猛烈抨击这份“错误”的白皮书，称东京“粗暴”干涉北京的内政并煽动地区紧张局势。

;

;日本的白皮书还强调了所构成的“迫在眉睫的威胁”并指出俄罗斯在该地区的军事活动以及与中国的战略协调具有“强烈的安全担忧”。

;

;“该地区知道日本对中国的战略态势比以前更加坚定新加坡南洋理工大学公共政策和全球事务副教授 Kei Koga 表示，“这显然是东南亚的一个担忧。”

;

;Koga 表示，日本一直在与东南亚国家保持密切沟通。东南亚国家联盟的国防和安全态势，并希望通过多边参与来缓解任何对抗。

;

;这种方法涵盖了东盟地区论坛以及其他东盟主导的会议上的讨论，其中包括他说，中国、韩国、澳大利亚、印度、新西兰、俄罗斯和美国是对话伙伴。

;

;“东京意识到过快扩大其在该地区安全作用的负面影响，新加坡拉惹勒南国际研究学院 (RSIS) 的副教授布布辛达尔·辛格 (Bhubhindar Singh) 表示，该学院的主要研究重点是日本的安全政策。

;

;辛格表示，东南亚国家并未对东京的安全政策提出新的担忧。最新的白皮书，因为它在12月发布的《国家安全战略》和《国防战略》文件中表达了类似观点。

;

;中国猛烈抨击日本“错误”的防卫白皮书

;

;Purnendra Jain阿德莱德大学亚洲研究系名誉教授表示，东南亚国家将继续通过自己的战略棱镜来看待中国，并独立评估自己的前景。

;

;“他们对于在两者之间做出选择犹豫不决。”中国和日本；事实上，他们希望与两者互动和接触。

;

;马尼拉国际发展与安全合作智库常驻研究员约书亚·伯纳德·埃斯佩尼亚 (Joshua Bernard Espeña) 表示，虽然东南亚国家担心关于日本如何“闭门”对中国崛起做出军事反应，地区精英可能理解东京的做法。

;

;“[他们]对中国的海上扩张有经验，”埃斯佩尼亚说，他指的是各国之间发生的小冲突例如越南和菲律宾在有争议的南中国海与中国船只发生过冲突。

;

;新加坡尤索夫伊萨东南亚研究所进行的 2023 年东南亚状况调查显示，日本成为东南亚最值得信赖的大国该地区的发展，主要归功于其数十年的发展援助和基础设施投资。

;

;

;

;到 2027 年，日本的目标是将其国防开支翻一番，达到国内生产总值的 2% 左右 –或五年内 43 万亿日元（3,032 亿美元）——比 2019 年至 2023 年期间的 17.2 万亿日元大幅增加。

;

;新的支出目标符合北约标准，并已确定将日本的年度预算增加到约 10 万亿日元，成为继美国和中国之后的世界第三大预算。

;

;Jain 表示，日本军费开支的增加已经开始，并且可能在未来四年内加速 - 不过该国人口减少和收入基础萎缩可能是一个挑战。

;

;东京早些时候表示，远程反击能力是阻止对日本的任何攻击，同时防御来袭导弹的关键。

;

;“这可能会导致该地区的“安全困境”，[或者]一个国家不断增强的军事实力会导致其他国家增强军事实力，”贾恩说，并补充说，“日本威胁认知中的游戏规则改变者”是战争

;

;他表示，北京和莫斯科的“无限制”伙伴关系“让日本战略家比以前更加不安”，并指出日本在首相岸田文雄的领导下在国防和安全问题上采取了不那么强硬的态度。他的前任安倍晋三。

;

;古贺说，日本的防卫白皮书“不是原因，而是战略形势的症状”。

;

;随着中美关系的紧张，预计会有更多表现北京与朝鲜的团结：分析师

;

;RSIS的辛格补充说，除了中国之外，日本对战略环境的不利解读也与朝鲜试图加强其核计划和弹道导弹计划有关。

;

;“对环境的这种解读已经并将影响日本的安全政策演变，以及在塑造该地区力量平衡方面日益增强的作用，”辛格说。

;

;上个月末，朝鲜发射了两枚导弹在美国核动力潜艇抵达韩国海军基地数小时后，朝鲜又将弹道导弹射入其东海岸海域。

;

;自 2022 年初以来，朝鲜已试射了约 100 枚导弹。 7月，最高领导人金正恩亲自监督了该国最新洲际弹道导弹——固体燃料火星18的发射。

;一家中国广告公司为“抗衰老”饮料开展性别歧视宣传活动该公司告诉女性，看起来更年轻会取悦生气的丈夫，因其在产品宣传中的作用而被罚款 48 万元（67,000 美元）。

;

;7 月 28 日，北京营销监督机构表示，红枣文化该公司的广告违反了“社会良好风尚”，违反了我国《广告法》。

;

;该机构被罚款22万元，并责令其缴纳广告制作后已支付的费用26万元。

;

; p>;

;该视频广告在没有证据的情况下声称，由同名美容产品公司生产的一款名为“五医生”的饮料富含胶原蛋白肽，具有抗衰老、抗皱和美白功效

;

;广告中的一句口号是：“一瓶这种饮料相当于用六个护肤面膜”。

;

;“我丈夫生我的气。喝！熬夜看电视剧。喝！我又大一岁了。喝吧，”一系列女演员在不同版本的广告中宣称。

;

;“胶原蛋白从我的身体中流失得很快，但五位医生可以帮助更快地补充它，”广告解说员声称。 “喝五医生。我必须喝，是被你逼的。”

;

;五医生是由五名女性创立的，她们都自称是2019年从北京大学医学部获得博士学位的。胶原蛋白肽饮料是其标志性产品。

;

;该公司因广告中的言论被罚款 40 万元人民币（56,000 美元）后，于 6 月公开道歉。

;

;“我们将坚决纠正我们的错误。”该公司在6月中旬的一份声明中表示：“我们对错误感到抱歉，并对我们的广告造成的恶劣影响向公众表示诚挚的歉意。”住宅楼和写字楼的电梯里。

;

;“太恶心了！其目的是对女性进行精神控制，让她们担心自己的年龄和外表。”一位网友表示。

;

;还有人问道：“这则广告怎么能获准公开展示？”

;

; >;

;性别歧视或不当广告产品经常在内地社交媒体上流行。

;

;一位为 Covid-19 mRNA 疫苗奠定基础的科学家表示希望未来，以类似技术为中心的药物可用于治愈伤口并预防从癌症到心脏病和过敏等多种疾病。

;

;匈牙利裔美国生物化学家 Katalin Kariko 教授没想到她 30 多年前开始的信使 RNA（mRNA）研究可以帮助开发在抗击流感大流行中至关重要的疫苗。

;

;“我没想到……我会成为众人瞩目的焦点”，68 岁的 Kariko 说，她周五在香港接受了香港中文大学的荣誉科学博士学位，以表彰她的救生工作。

;

;mRNA 疫苗在全球范围内广泛用于治疗 Covid-19，它使用信使RNA分子教导身体产生特殊的蛋白质并激活免疫细胞来针对病毒。

;

;Kariko目前是匈牙利塞格德大学的教授和宾夕法尼亚大学的兼职教授，他解释说RNA，存在于所有活细胞中，还可以帮助产生一种有助于愈合的蛋白质。

;

;“我预计 mRNA 对某些事情会有用。事实上，我想每个人的冰箱里都会有某种 RNA……主要用于伤口，”Kariko 说。 “也许他们在做饭时烧伤了手……你可以应用[RNA]并加速愈合。”

;

;美国制药巨头Moderna在香港。它的计划是什么？

;

;mRNA（RNA 的一种）于 1961 年首次被发现，它的作用就像一个携带重要指令的信使，指导细胞中负责蛋白质生产的部分。 Kariko 和宾夕法尼亚州的同事 Drew Weissman 教授找到了一种修改 mRNA 的方法，从而能够开发相关疫苗。

;

;Kariko 说，通过使用 mRNA 技术，疫苗的开发速度也可以更快。

;

; >;

;2020 年，在中国分享冠状病毒基因序列仅两个月后，制药公司 Moderna 就开始了 Covid-19 mRNA 疫苗的临床试验。 BioNTech 还与辉瑞合作，根据 Kariko 和她的团队的发现开发疫苗。

;

;她回忆说，2020 年底，当她看到周围的人排队接种疫苗时，她“哽咽”并“几乎哭了”，更少疫情爆发一年多后。

;

;尽管发展迅速，但也有人抱怨 mRNA 疫苗有副作用。据报道，注射了基于 mRNA 的 BioNTech 疫苗的香港居民，尤其是男性青少年，出现了心肌炎或心肌炎症。

;

;Moderna 表示二价新冠疫苗已获批在香港使用< /h3>;

;这些病例促使政府医疗顾问建议，应在儿童和青少年的大腿上注射 BioNTech 疫苗，以降低患心脏炎症的风险。

;

;“每种药物都有副作用， ” Kariko 指出，她说问题出在佐剂上，佐剂是疫苗中使用的一种成分，有助于在接受者中产生更强的免疫反应。

;

;“这种佐剂会增加炎症或激活免疫系统，”她说。< /p>;

;Kariko 同意 Covid-19 为公众提供了了解 mRNA 的机会并加速了该技术的发展，尽管其在预防或治疗各种疾病方面的应用研究早在大流行之前就已经开始了。< /p>;

;各种临床试验正在进行中，以了解 mRNA 在治疗中的潜力。世界各地的科学家开展了众多项目，其中包括针对胰腺癌和黑色素瘤的疫苗，以及治疗心脏病、花生和尘螨过敏的药物。

;

;而 Kariko 则因其出色的研究成果而获得了众多国际奖项。工作期间，她的职业道路一直坎坷不平，因为她之前一直难以获得研究经费。但她对一路上遇到的小问题表示感谢。

;

;“我要感谢那些试图让我的生活变得悲惨的人，因为他们让我变得更坚强……更有弹性，”她说，并把这归功于她的移民美国的背景让她决心永不放弃自己为之奋斗的事业。

;

;自开始注射疫苗以来，香港已丢弃了 50,000 剂新冠疫苗

;

;Covid-19 Kariko 成为人们关注的焦点，她希望利用这个机会来推广科学。

;

;“我感到有责任，”她说，并指出有机会激发年轻人对她的领域的兴趣。 “我希望他们看到科学很重要，成为一名科学家是一件令人兴奋的事情。”

;

;随着香港寻求成为国际生物技术中心，Kariko 表示，政府应该考虑提供“高质量的，负担得起的儿童保育”，这样女性科学家就可以继续工作。

;

;“我们需要女性，她们不会放弃，因为她们想要[组建家庭]，”卡里科说，她的女儿是美国奥运会赛艇冠军苏珊·弗兰西亚.她在科学上与她女儿的运动有相似之处，即运动员向后划船，看不到终点线。

;

;“我什至不知道自己是否走在正确的方向上。但我正在努力，”她说。

;根据意大利兰佩杜萨岛两起沉船事故，至少有 30 名移民失踪根据幸存者的证词，救援人员周日用绞车将另外 34 名被波涛汹涌的大海搁浅在岩石上的人救到安全地带。

;

;据幸存者报道，其中一艘船上约有 28 人在海上失踪，而第二艘船上则有 3 人失踪。国际移民组织 (IOM) 表示，周六两艘船均在暴风雨天气中沉没。

;

;这两艘船都是摇摇欲坠的铁船，据信周四从突尼斯斯法克斯出发。

;

;意大利海岸警卫队表示，已从两起沉船事故中救出 57 名幸存者，并打捞出一名妇女和一名儿童的尸体。

;

;周日，意大利海岸警卫队发布了救援行动的戏剧性镜头，其中可以看到人们的身影巨浪高高地冲上浪尖，一艘海岸警卫队船只在附近忽高忽低。

;

;当船只摇晃时，一些人试图爬上船只，而另一些人则戴着黑色橡胶圈，拼命地抓着一艘船。

;

;新闻官弗拉维奥·迪·贾科莫 (Flavio Di Giacomo) 表示，国际移民组织的文化调解员在与被从海浪中救出的人交谈后相信，“至少有 30 人失踪”。

;

;意大利总理梅洛尼寻求合作，遏制移民流向欧洲

;

;对附近意大利西西里岛阿格里真托的沉船事故调查已展开。

;

;阿格里真托警察局长埃马努埃莱·里西法里 (Emanuele Ricifari) 表示，贩运者会知道预报有恶劣天气。

;

;“无论是谁允许他们或强迫他们随这片海域离开，都是一个肆无忌惮的犯罪疯子，”他告诉意大利媒体。

;

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 07:20:02 +0800 Singaporean firm Mirxes enters Hong Kong to tap into growing multi-cancer early-stage screening market in Greater Bay Areahttps://www.scmp.com/business/china-business/article/3230087/singaporean-firm-mirxes-enters-hong-kong-tap-growing-multi-cancer-early-stage-screening-market?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.07 06:00;
;;

;Demand for multi-cancer early-stage screening products in China and across the broader Asia market is set for substantial expansion, as one in four people worldwide is now at risk of developing the disease, according to Singaporean diagnostics start-up Mirxes Holding, which is establishing a foothold in Hong Kong this year.

;

;Mirxes, a spin-off of Singapore's Agency for Science, Technology and Research, plans to make Hong Kong the base for its push into the larger Greater Bay Area (GBA) market, company co-founder and chief executive Zhou Lihan told the South China Morning Post.

;

;“Hong Kong is an excellent starting base for Mirxes' foray into the GBA given its accessibility and connection to the surrounding countries,” Zhou said in a recent interview. The GBA is a megalopolis that comprises the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau, and nine cities in southern Guangdong province, including its capital Guangzhou and tech hub Shenzhen.

;

;The move to Hong Kong by Mirxes, which launched the world's first molecular diagnostic kit for early detection of gastric cancer in 2019, followed the company's application in July for an initial public offering (IPO) in the city's stock exchange as part of its regional business expansion.

;

;The company aims to raise US$100 million to US$200 million from its Hong Kong IPO, according to people familiar with the matter. This would follow its US$50 million series D funding round.

;

;Its current focus on expanding operations in China reflects the growing number of cancer cases in the world's second-largest economy.

;

;“Cancer incidences have been increasing and the cost of treating cancer has also climbed significantly,” Zhou said. “Advances in cancer treatment alone are no longer sufficient to solve the burden of cancer, but early-detection solutions are necessary to improve the outcome of treatments.”

;

;He indicated that China accounted for 50 per cent of global stomach cancer patients. As such, he expected the company's molecular diagnostic kit for gastric cancer screening to meet demand in the country.

;

;Singaporean cancer screening start-up sets sights on China

;

;Mirxes, which had earlier introduced its diagnostic products in Asean countries, is currently developing new screening tests for lung, colorectal, liver and breast cancer.

;

;“The cancer burden has increased in many countries, ranging from 1.5 per cent to 2 per cent of gross domestic product,” Zhou said. “So early-detection solutions not only save lives, but also [translate to] savings on healthcare costs. When we have an early detection solution that can save costs commercially, the demand for it becomes a lot stronger.”

;

;“In terms of stomach, colon and lung cancer cases in the Asia-Pacific, we're looking at a market size of about US$10 billion to US$20 billion,” Zhou said.

;

;In Hong Kong, a total 34,719 of new cancer cases were diagnosed and 14,805 deaths were recorded in 2020, according to the latest data from the city's cancer registry.

;

;By 2040, the global cancer burden is expected to reach 27.5 million new cases and 16.3 million deaths amid the ageing population's steady increase, according to estimates from the International Agency for Research on Cancer.

;

;Zhou said Mirxes has started conversations with various potential collaborators in the GBA, including both clinical and insurance companies.

;

;The vast market for early-stage cancer screening has already attracted the interest of Hong Kong molecular biologist Dennis Lo, who pioneered non-invasive prenatal testing. Lo will launch a blood test kit with the city's Prenetics Group to find the genetic material of cancer cells.

;

;Zhou, however, described the market as big enough for more players.

;

;Hong Kong's DNA pioneers launch blood tests to find cancer

;

;The entire molecular cancer early detection industry is barely 10 years old, with the first US product only approved in 2014, according to Zhou.

;

;He said there are now seven major companies globally that are involved in cancer diagnostics products, including Mirxes and Hangzhou-based New Horizon Health, which is an investor in the Singaporean start-up.

;

;“None of us have even achieved five per cent of market share at present,” Zhou said. “Maybe after each of us achieves 10 to 20 per cent of market share, we may start to compete.”

;

;Regarding Mirxes' decision to list in Hong Kong, Zhou said since the launch of Chapter 18A, which enabled pre-revenue biotech companies to list, the city has built a good depth pool of sophisticated investors that understands the market.

;

;Still, Mirxes remains keen to grow in its home market of Singapore. While the firm has not revealed whether it will seek an IPO in the city state, Zhou indicated that Mirxes is open to all funding opportunities.

; Mon, 07 Aug 2023 06:20:02 +0800 Israel flirts with China to establish Saudi Arabia ties, but can ‘new kid on the block’ Beijing broker deal?https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3230145/israel-flirts-china-establish-saudi-arabia-ties-can-new-kid-block-beijing-broker-deal?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.07 06:00;
;;

;Israel's Benjamin Netanyahu may look to Beijing to help his country normalise relations with Saudi Arabia amid tensions with the United States, but challenges lie ahead for Beijing's role as a mediator because of its lack of leverage over the parties, analysts said.

;

;Netanyahu announced at the end of June that he had been invited to China. The news came just weeks after Chinese President Xi Jinping repeated Beijing's offer to mediate the Palestinian-Israeli conflict while hosting Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas.

;

;Originally planned for July, the trip is now likely to take place later this year – potentially in October, according to Israeli media. Chinese ambassador to Israel Cai Run told Netanyahu in a July 26 meeting that Xi looked forward to his visit, offering Beijing's first confirmation of the trip.

;

;Netanyahu's decision to travel to China was widely interpreted as a message to the US. The Israeli prime minister has not met US President Joe Biden since winning a November election amid tensions over Israel's settlements in the West Bank and controversial judicial reforms. Meanwhile, the US push to normalise ties between Israel and Saudi Arabia has yet to show clear progress.

;

;After his China trip was announced, Netanyahu received a delayed White House invitation to visit the US by the end of the year.

;

;Analysts said Netanyahu could still seek China's help to fast-track Israel's normalisation of ties with Saudi Arabia, though it could be a difficult task for Beijing, which recently brokered a landmark peace deal between the kingdom and Iran.

;

;Pan Guang, dean of the Centre of Jewish Studies Shanghai (CJSS), said seeking China's help would be one of Netanyahu's key missions when he came to China. He said China had leverage compared with the United States when it came to the mediation process, but the Israel-Palestine conflict would remain a challenge.

;

;“Compared with the United States, Saudi Arabia's relations with China are now on the rise, while its relations with the United States are on the decline,” he said.

;

;“The Democrat administration talks about human rights, which quite troubles the Saudis. China does not interfere with domestic affairs like human rights, so it will be easier to get things done.”

;

;China's Xi meets Mahmoud Abbas, offers 3-point plan to resolve Palestinian issue

;

;Riyadh has increasingly partnered with Beijing in various fields as it looks to diversify its oil-dominated economy, while its relations with Washington have become strained in recent years, particularly over the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

;

;But the US and Saudi Arabia have begun to show signs of a thaw in recent months, with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan visiting Riyadh on separate trips to refresh Washington's commitment to the region.

;

;The US has pushed for Israel's integration into the region by attempting to broker the normalisation of ties with Riyadh. But while more Arab countries, including the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, have established formal ties with Israel, no clear progress has been seen after rounds of separate talks with Saudi Arabia.

;

;In exchange for normalising ties with Israel, Riyadh reportedly demanded more security assurances, including advanced weapons sales, a US pledge to defend the kingdom if attacked and support for a civil nuclear programme that would allow domestic uranium enrichment – conditions Washington found too costly to accept.

;

;Meanwhile, the US pressed Israel to de-escalate tensions with the Palestinians and halt the judicial overhaul – which has prompted mass demonstrations over concerns it will undermine the country's democracy – in exchange for the normalisation of ties.

;

;Pan said China would face similar demands from both sides if it tried to mediate.

;

;“Saudi Arabia at least will ask for a halt to the building of settlements in the occupied [Palestinian] territories if establishing diplomatic relations with Israel,” he said, adding that the demand would probably not be accepted by Israel.

;

;Tuvia Gering, a researcher with the Diane and Guilford Glazer Israel-China Policy Centre at the Institute for National Security Studies (INSS) in Tel Aviv, said negotiations over Saudi-Israeli ties had so far only been arranged by the White House, and Riyadh appeared to be more interested in what it could possibly get from the US, such as F-35 fighter jets.

;

;“China would love nothing more than cutting the ribbon to Israeli-Saudi normalisation because these are two close US partners. And China [taking] the credit, that would send a huge signal to everyone,” he said.

;

;“So sure, if they can land it. But that's why I don't think they'll be able to … Israel is not Saudi Arabia. This is no imitation game. Israel does not play the China card with the US.”

;

;Netanyahu assured the US that it remained Israel's “irreplaceable” ally after he announced his China trip, despite reportedly saying in a classified briefing that China's involvement in the region could be useful to “compel” the US to increase its engagement in the region.

;

;Gering said Netanyahu's visit would be closely watched in the context of the US-China rivalry, but Israel had no intention of seeking China as an alternative to the US.

;

;“When you have Netanyahu or [de facto Saudi ruler] Mohammed bin Salman go to China, ostensibly it's with the eye of having the US recommit. Because it's one way of telling the US that, look, if you're leaving us behind and you're going to do your thing there and we need to maintain the balance, and for a successful offshore balancing, you want to have multiple players,” he said.

;

;However, there is “zero resemblance” between Israel and Saudi Arabia when it comes to “hedging bets or diversifying or having alternatives”, he said.

;

;Chinese leader 'personally intervened' to secure Saudi-Iran deal

;

;Observers also said they did not expect any breakthroughs in the Israeli-Palestinian peace process during Netanyahu's visit.

;

;Guy Burton, a Middle East specialist and adjunct professor at the Brussels School of Governance, said China had attempted a “balancing act” again by inviting Netanyahu and Abbas for back-to-back visits – something that had happened twice before in 2013 and 2017.

;

;Since 2013, China has offered a few peace proposals and organised symposia to call for a two-state solution, three-way dialogues, and coordinated international efforts to resolve the conflict. But these were often seen as lacking substance and results.

;

;Burton said Netanyahu's visit to China this time would most likely see Beijing reiterate its willingness to facilitate talks without offering any concrete plans considering the current status quo: tensions over settlement activities in the West Bank, Israeli military attacks in Jenin that killed a dozen Palestinians and the internal split in Palestine between Fatah and Hamas.

;

;“What you don't have with the Israelis and the Palestinians is any kind of peace process on the table … there's absolutely no will or capacity on either the Palestinian or Israeli side to do anything here.”

;

;However, “there's a signalling thing going on here”, he said of China's offer to mediate the conflict as the “new kids on the block”.

;

;“It is a slight dig at the Americans saying, you know, you guys are nowhere,” Burton said.

;

;Formal peace talks between Israel and Palestine have been frozen since 2014 after the US-brokered process was halted because of a reconciliation between Fatah and Hamas, the two main Palestinian political parties. The latter governs the Gaza Strip and is known for its armed resistance against Israel.

;

;The deal led to the brief formation of a unity government led by Abbas, but it eventually fell apart in 2015 because of divisions between the two parties.

;

;Yin Gang, a Middle Eastern affairs specialist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences' Institute of West Asian and African Studies, said without internal unity in Palestine, there would not be much space for China to mediate the conflict.

;

;He said Netanyahu might press China to use its influence on Iran, which has long funded Hamas to counter Israel and the United States in the region.

;

;“In other words, Iran needs a Palestine-Israel conflict,” he said. “In the absence of effective internal management. Israeli-Palestinian peace talks are unlikely to lead to anything.”

;

;Pan of the CJSS said Netanyahu was less likely to focus on Iran while meeting Xi.

;

;“It is impossible for him to develop relations with Iran now. Iran's perception that Israel should not exist is a deadlock … So he won't talk about Iran now. The US will not play a role in this either,” he said.

;

;Gering of the INSS said Israel lacked the will to seek China as a mediator, and China was not serious about getting involved in the conflict, considering it had previously offered mostly “rhetoric” rather than action in its peace initiatives.

;

;He said a meeting with Netanyahu would be “just a marketing platform” for China's Global Development Initiative and Global Civilisation Initiative, which seek to present an alternative to the US-led global order.

;

;“For China, it's important to show that it's a responsible major player. It's important for it to juxtapose its engagement in conflict mediation versus the US.”

;

;He said the meeting would focus mainly on trade, offering a chance for the two partners to re-engage and explore new cooperation opportunities after three years of Covid-19.

;

;China is Israel's second-biggest trade partner, and a free-trade pact between the two is expected this year, according to Israeli media. During Netanyahu's last visit to China in 2017, the two countries established an Innovative Comprehensive Partnership, making Israel the second country – besides Switzerland – to forge such a relationship with China.

;

;China's hi-tech investments in Israel peaked in 2018 before dropping amid increased scrutiny from the US, according to data from the INSS. The country tightened its foreign investment restrictions on national security grounds last year in response to US pressure to limit Chinese investments in sensitive sectors.

;The New York Police Department (NYPD) announced on Sunday it is searching for a woman who was seen on a viral video shouting at an Asian family on the city's subway and confronting the passenger filming the altercation.

;

;Police said the woman is wanted for assault. In a social media post, the police department said the incident occurred on the evening of August 3, on a southbound F train at West 4th Street.

;

;The video showed three young women sitting across from an Asian family with two children, shouting at the family for unclear reasons. The woman who took the video wrote in a caption that the women were “harassing” the family and said she chose to start filming because she “knew it was going to get bad.”

;

;The video shows one of the women repeatedly rushing over to the woman filming, though the footage cuts out before any violence is shown.

;

;“This ferocious one runs over to hit me. I put down my phone to cover my head and took the blow (ow),” one of the video's captions said.

;

;The video then showed a brawl involving multiple passengers. A video caption said the woman filming was dragged by the hair and hit several times until she rolled away.

;

;A caption on the video said the incident ended at the next subway stop, when everyone involved exited the carriage. She said she spoke to the mother of the family and shared the videos with her to help in filing a police report.

;

;Is under-reporting behind drop in anti-Asian hate attacks in California?

;

;The video has prompted outrage, particularly in New York City, where an uptick of anti-Asian attacks in recent years has stoked fear among Asian communities. In response, the NYPD created the Asian Hate Crime Task Force soon after the Covid-19 pandemic began, citing a sevenfold increase in reports of anti-Asian harassment, discrimination, and violence since February 2020.

;

;The NYPD's social media post said one of the women seen in the video sparked a “dispute” with a 51-year-old victim, and “made an anti-ethnic remark, pulled her by the hair & punched her.” The police department urged anyone with further information about the identity of the woman to come forward.

;

;The NYPD did not immediately respond to Business Insider's request for further details about the altercation.

;;2023.08.07 06:15;
;;

;Did you know that if you Google “Barbie”, your search results and the Google logo come back in bright pink?

;

;That's the power of a plastic doll that made its debut in 1959. , the film, has broken record after record at the box office.

;

;It was the biggest opening in North America this year, raking in US$162 million there and US$194 million elsewhere. It made more money over the opening weekend for studio Warner Bros than any other non-DC Comics film or a sequel. It was also the biggest opening and grosser for a female director.

;

;How writer and director Greta Gerwig transformed the pink world of a toy that has not been without controversy into feminist feast on-screen is an absolute wonder.

;

;The Barbie doll had feminist roots – when it hit the shelves more than six decades ago, it was the first mass-produced doll with adult features. Barbie was the creator's response to girls being limited to playing with baby dolls, imagining themselves growing up to only be a mother.

;

;Barbie encouraged girls to dream about being anything they want – that is, if they had a highly unrealistic 18-inch waist and were blonde. From very early on, people noted Barbie's ridiculous body proportions and raised concerns over its promotion of an unhealthy body image.

;

;The Barbie doll series has also been criticised for its lack of ethnic diversity. Some, not all, girls can become anything they want.

;

;In the 1990s, a talking version was released and let's just say that “Math class is tough” and “Want to go shopping?” didn't go down well.

;

;Gerwig addresses these struggles of the 60-year-old doll trying to keep up with the times, and more, in her blockbuster. It's not radical feminism, or anti-men. It shows that the unattainably perfect – Barbie Land – is not perfect at all.

;

;When the hot pink utopia collides with the real world, we get to see real women, their struggles and achievements. At least there's room for motherhood in the real world. The film confronts both idealised femininity and idealised feminism.

;

;But, apparently, Barbie isn't doing very well in South Korea, where it only took in an 8 per cent share of the total box office. A Korean women's rights activist said women may be hesitant to be seen as supporting an overtly women-centred film for “fear of being labelled as a feminist”.

;

;That's understandable, especially when South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol, having previously suggested that feminism was to blame for the country's low birth rate, called himself a feminist on the campaign trail and then retracted that description. Feminism is perceived negatively in the country as an extreme and absurd quest for “female supremacy”.

;

;I'm grateful that, in Hong Kong, we can openly speak about gender equality, the gender pay gap and the need to empower and support women in the workplace, and that these discussions aren't treated as “radical”.

;

;Recall our chief executive, in marking International Women's Day, showing off a photo of himself flanked by his administration's six female principal officials. Women occupying 23 per cent of the positions in the city's top echelon of power is indeed worth celebrating.

;

;It's unfortunate that the Hong Kong team's historic win in their division of the Ice Hockey Women's World Championship in April was overshadowed by a war of words over a blunder related to the national anthem.

;

;In June, the government launched the Women Empowerment Fund with HK$100 million (US$12.8 million) earmarked from this year's budget to strengthen support for women's development programmes by women's organisations and NGOs. It is a definite step in the right direction.

;

;But then we have lawmaker Junius Ho Kwan-yiu, who in response to a motion in the Legislative Council on “promoting the comprehensive development of women in Hong Kong” ahead of Mother's Day in May, said, “I think men should now be protected” and lamented that women are “doing whatever they like”. Ho mistakenly attributed that to be why “men are now tied by many traditional shackles and have a lot of unspeakable pain”.

;

;However, it's not empowering women that causes men unspeakable pain. It is gender inequality that is shackling men and women. So go on Ho, we won't think any less of you if you watch Barbie.

;
